awd_titl_txt: Convergence Accelerator Phase I (RAISE): A Universal Framework of Micro-Credentials for Nation-Wide Employment
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.  

The broader impact/potential benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project will be to increase opportunities for American workers to earn recognition for specific knowledge and skills in ways that connect them to jobs. This benefit will be made possible by the creation of a micro-credentialing system that uses partnerships between higher education and employers to co-develop industry-valued skills and knowledge that can be taught and verified. A micro-credential is a credential that focuses on specific high-demand competencies, can be earned in online, work-based, or even informal settings, and can generally be earned in less time and at less cost than conventional post-secondary credentials. This system will employ a convergent approach, bringing together expert faculty, researchers, employers and job-seekers from industries that currently include talent and recruiting, data science, engineering, and others - all to address a challenge that can only be met by collaborative efforts. The resultant system for implementing micro-credentials will be scalable to ensure that diverse institutions are able to efficiently and effectively collaborate with employers to execute programs that directly address the needs of the workforce, thereby impacting employability on a national scale.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase I project addresses a need for a national talent ecosystem that responds to employers seeking individuals with 21st century skills. Success in an increasingly, globally competitive economy requires that employers be able to quickly hire to match specific workforce needs - a process that traditional credentials cannot address alone. This challenge is also a significant opportunity to research the resources and strategies that are needed to better match job-seekers with high demand skills to their future employers. This project will form a partnership of job-seekers, educators, and employers to co-design a universal model of a micro-credential program that can be deployed at any higher education institution to accommodate regional or national employment needs. Research will focus on the processes, procedures, and resources that are necessary to implement micro-credentials, as well as how the (multi-stakeholder) design teams operate, leading to creating theory and operational findings on how micro-credentials can be designed to ensure quality, sustainability, and stakeholder acceptance. Outcomes from the project will be a network of openly licensed, scalable, and customizable micro-credential systems and a research base that can support further development of improved credentialing processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes:
This Convergence Accelerator grant was the result of a collaboration between the University at Buffalo SUNY and the University at Montana-Western, representing public institutions that serve both urban and rural populations. Our main goal was to create a universal and flexible framework that would allow higher-education institutions to implement and sustain micro-credentials that directly address employer needs. To achieve this goal, we designed and implemented model micro-credential programs and then tested the applicability of the framework?s primary components (e.g., stakeholder engagement). This led to a greater understanding of how the inherent characteristics (e.g., mission, size, semester length) of an institution can influence how a micro-credential program is developed and implemented. We also concluded that our framework, when applied in full, resulted in development of micro-credentials that serve the respective population attending the respective higher education organization. This is a major finding, in that the populations attending different higher education organizations are heterogeneous and not homogeneous, and so micro-credentials must accommodate that heterogeneity. In practical terms, micro-credential programs in higher education must accommodate regional and cultural ways to recruit students, faculty, and employers to first co-design micro-credentials, and then disseminate example micro-credentials and supporting materials. These materials then seed further micro-credential development at the institution.  

Intellectual Merit:
Prior to our project, the majority of micro-credential programs developed in higher education are for singular purposes (e.g., stakeholder engagement, financial considerations, governance). In other words, micro-credentials are implemented to address one particular need. In addition, despite the growth of micro-credentials throughout higher education, there is little known about how faculty perceive micro-credentials, or the design-role that faculty assume when a university implements a micro-credential program.
Our project proves that consideration of several operational needs is critical for a university-wide micro-credential program. In addition, other critical factors include supporting quality design of micro-credentials, including design principles, and recommendations for professional development for faculty-designers. These enhancements are a direct result from the findings of our research examining faculty perceptions of micro-credentials. We found that faculty perceived micro-credentials to offer both assessment and credentialing affordances. This finding led us to examine the extent to which faculty designed micro-credentials to serve as quality assessments and as quality credentials. Findings revealed that faculty may need support in recognizing and integrating certain principles of good assessment design when designing micro-credentials. These findings enhanced our micro-credential framework?s focus on quality and continuous improvement practices.

Broader Impacts:
Throughout the duration of the project, we have increased our model?s applicability across higher education and enhanced its capacity to support the development of quality micro-credentials for nation-wide employment. Additionally, the framework has been enhanced by insights of stakeholders (e.g., academic leadership, faculty) from other institutions across the country. Over the course of this project we held informal discussions, workshops, and consultations with over 50 institutions of higher education. These institutions comprised different types (e.g., private; community college, technical college) as well as various population sizes and demographics. This work allowed us to share the framework broadly, and support a multitude of micro-credential development and implementation efforts. A reciprocal approach to this work provided a wealth of knowledge regarding institutional needs for offering micro-credentials. Through these meetings we were able to recognize components of a micro-credential system that are widely applicable (e.g., technical infrastructure) as well as those that are dependent upon unique aspects of the institution (e.g., collaboration with non-academic organizations). Integration of this knowledge into the framework has contributed to legitimizing the designation of the project as a ?universal? framework of micro-credentials for nation-wide employment.
